natural problem:
Which of the following numbers is the smallest? Your answer is the letter in front of the smallest number.

$\bullet$ A. $14.45001$ rounded to the nearest tenth.

$\bullet$ B. $14.54999$ rounded to the nearest tenth.

$\bullet$ C. $14.44999$ rounded to the nearest tenth.

$\bullet$ D. $14.55001$ rounded to the nearest tenth.
natural solution: All of these numbers need to be rounded to the nearest tenth.
To do this, we look at the places after the tenths place.

We see two different endings: $0.05001$ and $0.04999.$ Because the $0.05001$ is greater than $0.05,$ we will round the tenths place up in numbers that end in this. In addition, because $0.04999$ is less than $0.05,$ numbers with this ending will be rounded down.
Thus, after rounding according to these rules, we get $\bullet$ A. $14.5$ $\bullet$ B. $14.5$ $\bullet$ C. $14.4$ $\bullet$ D. $14.6$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: real
assumes h0 : "A = round (14.45001 * 10) / 10"
and h1 : "B = round (14.54999 * 10) / 10"
and h2 : "C = round (14.44999 * 10) / 10"
and h3 : "D = round (14.55001 * 10) / 10"
shows  "min (min (min A B) C) D = C"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Which of the following numbers is the smallest? Your answer is the letter in front of the smallest number.

$\bullet$ A. $14.45001$ rounded to the nearest tenth.

$\bullet$ B. $14.54999$ rounded to the nearest tenth.

$\bullet$ C. $14.44999$ rounded to the nearest tenth.

$\bullet$ D. $14.55001$ rounded to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is \text{C}
 ### Proof
 All of these numbers need to be rounded to the nearest tenth.
 To do this, we look at the places after the tenths place.
 We see two different endings: $0.05001$ and $0.04999.$ Because the $0.05001$ is greater than $0.05,$ we will round the tenths place up in numbers that end in this. In addition, because $0.04999$ is less than $0.05,$ numbers with this ending will be rounded down.
 Thus, after rounding according to these rules, we get $\bullet$ A. $14.5$ $\bullet$ B. $14.5$ $\bullet$ C. $14.4$ $\bullet$ D. $14.6$
 Thus, $\boxed{\text{C}}$ is the smallest.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: real
assumes h0 : "A = round (14.45001 * 10) / 10"
and h1 : "B = round (14.54999 * 10) / 10"
and h2 : "C = round (14.44999 * 10) / 10"
and h3 : "D = round (14.55001 * 10) / 10"
shows  "min (min (min A B) C) D = C"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Let A be the rounded value of 14.45001 to the nearest tenth, B be the rounded value of 14.54999 to the nearest tenth, C be the rounded value of 14.44999 to the nearest tenth, and D be the rounded value of 14.55001 to the nearest tenth. What is the smallest value among A, B, C, and D? The final Answer is C.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: real
assumes h0 : "A = round (14.45001 * 10) / 10"
and h1 : "B = round (14.54999 * 10) / 10"
and h2 : "C = round (14.44999 * 10) / 10"
and h3 : "D = round (14.55001 * 10) / 10"
shows  "C < min A (min B D)"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Which of the following numbers is the smallest? Your answer is the letter in front of the smallest number.

$\bullet$ A. $14.45001$ rounded to the nearest tenth.

$\bullet$ B. $14.54999$ rounded to the nearest tenth.

$\bullet$ C. $14.44999$ rounded to the nearest tenth.

$\bullet$ D. $14.55001$ rounded to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is \text{C}
 ### Proof
 All of these numbers need to be rounded to the nearest tenth.
 To do this, we look at the places after the tenths place.
 We see two different endings: $0.05001$ and $0.04999.$ Because the $0.05001$ is greater than $0.05,$ we will round the tenths place up in numbers that end in this. In addition, because $0.04999$ is less than $0.05,$ numbers with this ending will be rounded down.
 Thus, after rounding according to these rules, we get $\bullet$ A. $14.5$ $\bullet$ B. $14.5$ $\bullet$ C. $14.4$ $\bullet$ D. $14.6$
 Thus, $\boxed{\text{C}}$ is the smallest.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: real
assumes h0 : "A = round (14.45001 * 10) / 10"
and h1 : "B = round (14.54999 * 10) / 10"
and h2 : "C = round (14.44999 * 10) / 10"
and h3 : "D = round (14.55001 * 10) / 10"
shows  "C < min A (min B D)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Round the following numbers to one decimal place: 14.45001, 14.54999, 14.44999, and 14.55001. Determine if the rounded value of 14.44999 is less than the minimum of the other three rounded values.

a_2.informal problem:
Find the minimum value among the following rounded numbers: 

1. The number obtained by rounding 14.45001 to the nearest tenth.
2. The number obtained by rounding 14.54999 to the nearest tenth.
3. The number obtained by rounding 14.44999 to the nearest tenth.
4. The number obtained by rounding 14.55001 to the nearest tenth.

The minimum value is the rounded version of 14.44999.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d :: real
assumes h0 : "a = round (14.45001 * 10) / 10"
and h1 : "b = round (14.54999 * 10) / 10"
and h2 : "c = round (14.44999 * 10) / 10"
and h3 : "d = round (14.55001 * 10) / 10"
shows  "min (min (min a b) c) d = c"
a_3.formal solution:

and h3 : "d = round (14.55001 * 10) / 10"
shows  "min (min (min a b) c) d = c"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Round the following numbers to the nearest tenth: 14.45001, 14.54999, 14.44999, 14.55001. Which of these rounded numbers is the smallest? The smallest is the rounded number of 14.44999.

a_4.informal problem: Round the numbers 14.45001, 14.54999, 14.44999, and 14.55001 to the nearest integer. Compare the rounded value of 14.44999 with the rounded values of the other three numbers. The rounded value of 14.44999 will be less than the rounded values of the other three numbers.

and h2 : "C = round(14.44999 * 10) / 10"

a_5.informal problem: Round the following four numbers to the nearest tenth: 14.45001, 14.54999, 14.44999, and 14.55001. What is the smallest of these four rounded numbers? The final answer is the rounded value of 14.44999.

a_7.informal problem: Round the following numbers to the nearest whole number: 14.45001, 14.54999, 14.44999, and 14.55001. What is the smallest of these rounded numbers? The final answer is the rounded version of 14.44999.

theorem smallest_number
fixes A B C D :: real

and h3 : "D = round (14.55001 * 10) / 10"
shows  "C < A \<and> C < B \<and> C < D"

fixes A B C D :: real
